lhsLabels.description: Section header for the preprocessing section
Overview of the three preprocessing steps: padding the message, parsing the message, and setting the initial hash value
Subsection header for padding the message
Explanation of the purpose of padding to ensure the message is a multiple of 512 or 1024 bits
Subsubsection header for SHA-1, SHA-224 and SHA-256 padding
Detailed algorithm for padding messages in SHA-1, SHA-224 and SHA-256, including the formula for calculating padding bits and an example
Reference to an image showing padded message representation
Post-condition that the padded message length must be a multiple of 512 bits
Subsection header for parsing the message
Brief statement that the message and padding must be parsed into m-bit blocks
Subsubsection header for SHA-1, SHA-224 and SHA-256 parsing
Specification of how messages are parsed into 512-bit blocks for SHA-1, SHA-224 and SHA-256, and how these blocks are represented as 32-bit words
Subsection header for setting the initial hash value
Explanation that an initial hash value must be set before hash computation begins
Subsubsection header for SHA-1 initial hash value
Specification of the five 32-bit words that constitute the initial hash value for SHA-1, given in hexadecimal
Section header for secure hash algorithms
Explanation of why algorithms are not presented in ascending order of size, noting relationships between SHA-256/SHA-224 and SHA-512/SHA-384/SHA-512/224/SHA-512/256
Statement that alternate computation methods yielding identical results are acceptable implementations
Subsection header for SHA-1
Overview of SHA-1 algorithm, including input constraints, components used, and output size
Definition of the variables and notation used in the SHA-1 algorithm, including message schedule words, working variables, hash value words, and temporary word
Subsubsection header for SHA-1 preprocessing
Two-step process for SHA-1 preprocessing: setting initial hash value and padding/parsing the message
Subsubsection header for SHA-1 hash computation
Reference to previously defined functions and constants used in SHA-1, and specification that addition is performed modulo 2^32
Introduction to the message block processing steps for SHA-1
Detailed algorithm for SHA-1 hash computation, including message schedule preparation, working variable initialization, the main processing loop, and intermediate hash value computation
Final step of SHA-1 algorithm showing how the 160-bit message digest is formed from the final hash value
